posts.title: CatalyzeH20 Receives $75,000 Small Business Award
posts.content:
University of Arkansas-based startup CatalyzeH20 is bringing innovation to the water treatment industry by creating nanotechnology and electrochemical solutions to cleanse water of contaminants.

  • Join the conversation: Aaron Ivy, a Rogers native and Vice President of CatalyzeH20, recently shared about the company's work, their experience at the NWA Tech Summit, and the support they've received from the University of Arkansas on episode 42 of The Bentonville Beacon.
  • Military funding: The group was recently awarded a $75,000 Small Business Innovation and Research Award from the Department of Defense to aid the development of their Ozark Reactor, a water treatment system designed to eliminate PFAS from contaminated water.

Learn more about CatalyzeH20 HERE.

posts.title: J.B. Hunt Participates In Wreaths Across America For Ninth Year
posts.content:
For the ninth consecutive year, J.B. Hunt Transport Services will participate in Wreaths Across America, delivering wreaths to decorate veteran cemeteries.

  • Honored: Wreaths Across America places millions of wreaths on the graves of fallen soldiers each year to help others remember fallen veterans, honor those who've served, and to teach the value of freedom.
  • Special freight: This year, 70 J.B. Hunt drivers will participate in transporting approximately 287,000 wreaths to veteran cemeteries across the country, and the company has customized 12 tractors and 4 trailers with military-themed wrap to commemorate the event.

Read the full story HERE.

posts.title: Turpentine Creek Wildlife Celebrates Approval Of Big Cat Safety Act
posts.content:
Turpentine Creek Wildlife Refuge in Eureka Springs is celebrating the U.S. Senate approval of the Big Cat Public Safety Act and plans to take in new cats when able.

  • Purrfect: The passing of this legislation would make it illegal for individuals to own big cats and put an end to pay-for-play and cub-petting operations, which is the main driver for the overbreeding of exotic cats.
  • Forever home: Turpentine Creek exists to provide lifetime refuge for abused and neglected “Big Cats” with an emphasis on tigers, lions, leopards, and cougars; though, they are also home to several bears, bobcats, and even a hyena named Rambo.

Read more from Arkansas Money & Politics HERE.

posts.title: Devil's Den State Park Hosts Open House For New Amenities
posts.content:
Devil's Den State Park will host an open house to celebrate the new Devil's Racetrack Trailhead, parking area, restrooms, and changing stalls tomorrow, Dec 14, at 1:30p.

  • Hike, bike, camp: The Racetrack is part of the Monument Trails, a system of world-class mountain biking trails, and the completed project now offers seven new hike-in or bike-in backcountry-style campsites that can be accessed through the new parking area.
  • Horsin' around: Devil's Racetrack Trailhead is located west of the horse camp on Arkansas Highway 220, aka Lee Creek Rd.

Read more on Arkansas Outside and find a map of the new trailhead HERE.

posts.title: ArDOT Receiving Feedback On Proposed Highway 112 Project
posts.content:
Arkansas Department of Transportation is hosting two in-person meetings this week, today, Dec 13, and Thursday, Dec 15, to share plans and receive feedback for a proposed $193.2m project to widen Arkansas Highway 112.

  • Up the corridor: The proposed plan would widen Highway 112 to four lanes with a median, bike path, and sidewalk stretching from Highway 12 in Bentonville to Highway 412 in Tontitown.
  • Meet up: The meeting today will be hosted from 4-7p at Elm Springs United Methodist Church, focusing on the segment between Highway 412 and 612; then, Thursday's meeting from 4-7p will take place at the Bentonville Community Center, addressing the segment between Highway 612 and 12.

Learn more about this project HERE,

pick.title: NWA Daily Picks
pick.content:
• That's pretty neat: The NEAT Method is offering NWA Daily subscribers a free consultation to learn about their outstanding organization services.*
  • Musical telegram: Give the gift that keeps on singing by sending your musical friends a Big Box Karaoke gift card for Christmas this year.*
  • Safety first: The city of Decatur received a $46,000 grant to cover the cost of body cams for the police department and $200,000 to add new sidewalks around town.
  • Cap and gown: Almost 1,400 graduating students will walk the stage in Bud Walton Arena during the U of A's fall commencement on Dec 17.
  • Detour: The Razorback Greenway will be closed between West Center St and West Meadow St in Fayetteville while crews replace the aging asphalt with new concrete.
  • Let's talk: Interested in advertising in the newsletter? Check out our deals HERE.

*Content is sponsored
